tooltip.FS: Friction sensitivity, measured in Newtons, indicating the force at which the material ignites under friction.
tooltip.nH: Number of hydrogen atoms per molecule. Used to estimate contribution of hydrogen to sensitivity.
tooltip.nN: Number of nitrogen atoms per molecule. Nitrogen-rich explosives often have different sensitivity behavior.
tooltip.nO: Number of oxygen atoms per molecule, affecting oxygen balance and sensitivity.
tooltip.Mw: Molecular weight in g/mol, affects normalization of atom ratios.
tooltip.Pplus: Positive polarity parameter (Pauling scale), related to electrostatic properties.
tooltip.Pminus: Negative polarity parameter (Pauling scale), related to electron-withdrawing effects.

Friction Sensitivity (FS).source: Meyer, R. et al., Explosives, 6th Edition, Wiley-VCH, 2007.

tooltip.ρ: Density of the energetic material in g/cm³, crucial for detonation performance.
tooltip.M: Molar mass of the molecule in g/mol.
tooltip.V0001: Molar volume at a reference condition V(0.001), in cm³/mol.
tooltip.νσtot2: Mean-square total vibrational frequency in kcal²/mol², linked to crystal packing.

Density (ρ).source: Rice, B.M. & Hare, J.J., 'A quantum mechanical investigation of the relation between impact sensitivity and the charge distribution in energetic molecules', J. Phys. Chem. A, 106(9), 1770–1783 (2002).

tooltip.P: Detonation pressure in GPa at the Chapman–Jouguet point.
tooltip.N: Moles of gas per gram of explosive.
tooltip.M: Average molecular mass of gaseous detonation products in g/mol.
tooltip.Qmax: Maximum heat of explosion in kcal/kg.

Detonation Pressure at Chapman-Jouguet p.source: Kamlet, M.J. & Jacobs, S.J., 'Chemistry of Detonations', J. Chem. Phys., 48(1), 23–35 (1968).

tooltip.P: Detonation pressure in GPa from Pepekin–Lebedev model.
tooltip.neff: Effective number of moles of gaseous detonation products per gram.
tooltip.ρ: Density of the explosive in g/cm³.

Detonation Pressure at Chapman-Jouguet p.source: Pepekin, V.I. & Lebedev, E.N., 'Evaluation of detonation characteristics of condensed explosives', Combustion, Explosion, and Shock Waves, 9(2), 202–206 (1973).

tooltip.P: Detonation pressure in GPa from Smirnov–Smirnov empirical model.
tooltip.ρ: Density of the explosive in g/cm³.
tooltip.Qmax: Maximum heat of explosion in kcal/kg.
tooltip.Ng: Moles of gas produced per kg of explosive.

Detonation Pressure at Chapman-Jouguet p.source: Smirnov, N.N. & Smirnov, S.P., 'Semi-empirical methods for estimating detonation parameters', Combustion, Explosion, and Shock Waves, 10(1), 61–68 (1974).

tooltip.h50: Height (in cm) at which 50% initiation probability occurs in drop-weight impact tests.
tooltip.νσtot2: Mean-square total vibrational frequency in kcal²/mol².

tooltip.h50: Drop height for 50% probability of initiation, in cm.
tooltip.σplus2: Mean-square positive vibrational frequency in kcal²/mol².
tooltip.ν: Number of moles of gaseous products per mole of explosive.

Impact sensitivity (h50) - Nitramines.source: Fedorov, A., et al., 'Correlation of sensitivity and molecular structure for nitramines', Propellants, Explosives, Pyrotechnics, 17(3), 107–112 (1992).

tooltip.D: Detonation velocity in km/s from KJ model.
tooltip.N: Moles of gas per gram of explosive.
tooltip.M: Average molecular mass of gaseous products in g/mol.
tooltip.Qmax: Maximum heat of explosion in kcal/kg.

Detonation velocity (D) - Kamlet Jacobs.source: Kamlet, M.J. & Jacobs, S.J., J. Chem. Phys., 48(1), 23–35 (1968).

tooltip.D: Detonation velocity in km/s from PL model.
tooltip.neff: Effective moles of gas per gram.

Detonation velocity (D) - Pepekin-Lebede.source: Pepekin, V.I. & Lebedev, E.N., Combustion, Explosion, and Shock Waves, 9(2), 202–206 (1973).

tooltip.D: Detonation velocity in km/s from SS empirical model.

Detonation velocity (D) - Smirnov-Smirno.source: Smirnov, N.N. & Smirnov, S.P., Combustion, Explosion, and Shock Waves, 10(1), 61–68 (1974).

tooltip.ΔHsub: Heat required to sublimate one mole of solid explosive, in kcal/mol.
tooltip.A: Surface area per molecule in Å².
tooltip.νσtot2: Mean-square total vibrational frequency in kcal²/mol².

tooltip.EES: Predicts sensitivity to electric sparks. Higher EES = more sensitive.

Electric Spark Sensitivity (EES).source: Pospíšil et al., Propellants, Explosives, Pyrotechnics (2010).

tooltip.OB: Measures oxygen surplus/deficit relative to CO2/H2O formation. OB ≈ 0 is ideal for explosives.
tooltip.nC: Number of carbon atoms per molecule.
tooltip.nH: Number of hydrogen atoms per molecule.
tooltip.nO: Number of oxygen atoms per molecule.

tooltip.√2E: Energy imparted to metal fragments during detonation.
tooltip.ρ: Density of the energetic material in g/cm³, crucial for detonation performance.

tooltip.AIT: Lower AIT = higher sensitivity to heat.

tooltip.EPI: Higher EPI = better performance (balance of velocity, pressure, and safety).
tooltip.h50: Height (in cm) at which 50% initiation probability occurs in drop-weight impact tests.

Explosive Performance Index (EPI).source: Empirical model based on detonation parameters.
